hints_html: To calculate \(dq/dp\) you can use implicit differentiation. Alternatively, you can solve for \(q\) in terms of \(p\) and then differentiate.
hints_latex:
To calculate $dq/dp$ you can use implicit differentiation.
Alternatively, you can solve for $q$ in terms of $p$ and then
differentiate.
hints_raw: To calculate <math>dq/dp</math> you can use implicit differentiation.  Alternatively, you can solve for <math>q</math> in terms of <math>p</math> and then differentiate.
question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
To determine \(q\) when \(p = 4\) is simply a matter of substituting \(p = 4\) into the demand equation and solving for \(q\).

\[\begin{aligned} q^{2} + p^{3/2} + 2p &= 20 \\ q^{2} + 8 + 8 &= 20 \\ q^{2} &= 4 \\ q &= \pm 2.\end{aligned}\]

We ignore the negative solution since it is not possible to have negative demand. Therefore \({\color{blue}q =2}.\)

To determine \(dq/dp\), we use implicit differentiation.

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dp}\left(q^{2} + p^{3/2} + 2p\right) &= \frac{d}{dp}\left(20\right) \\ 2q\frac{dq}{dp} + \frac{3}{2}p^{1/2} + 2 &= 0 \\ \frac{dq}{dp} &= \frac{1}{2q}\left(-2 - \frac{3}{2}p^{1/2} \right)\end{aligned}\]

Substituting the values \(p = 4,\,q = 2\) into the expression gives the value of \(dq/dp\):

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dq}{dp} &= \frac{1}{4}\left(-2 - 3\right) \quad \rightarrow \quad {\color{blue}\frac{dq}{dp}}\,&{\color{blue}= -\frac{5}{4}}\end{aligned}\]

Instead of implicitly differentiating, we first solve the equation for q and then differentiate normally.

\[\begin{aligned} q^2+p^{3/2}+2p &=20 \\ q^2 &=20-p^{3/2}-2p \\ q &=\sqrt{20-p^{3/2}-2p}\end{aligned}\]

Then

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dq}{dp} = \frac{-(3/2)p^{1/2}-2}{2\sqrt{20-p^{3/2}-2p}}\end{aligned}\]

Substituting in \(p = 4\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dq}{dp} = \frac{-(3/2)(4)^{1/2}-2}{2\sqrt{20-(4)^{3/2}-2(4)}} = \frac{-(3/2)(2)-2}{2\sqrt{20-8-8}} = \frac{-5}{4}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
To determine $q$ when $p = 4$ is simply a matter of substituting $p = 4$
into the demand equation and solving for $q$.

\begin{align*}
q^{2} + p^{3/2} + 2p &= 20 \\
q^{2} + 8 + 8 &= 20 \\
q^{2} &= 4 \\
q &= \pm 2.
\end{align*} We ignore the negative solution since it is not possible
to have negative demand. Therefore ${\color{blue}q =2}.$

To determine $dq/dp$, we use implicit differentiation.

\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dp}\left(q^{2} + p^{3/2} + 2p\right) &= \frac{d}{dp}\left(20\right) \\
2q\frac{dq}{dp} + \frac{3}{2}p^{1/2} + 2 &= 0 \\
\frac{dq}{dp} &= \frac{1}{2q}\left(-2 - \frac{3}{2}p^{1/2} \right)
\end{align*} Substituting the values $p = 4,\,q = 2$ into the
expression gives the value of $dq/dp$:

\begin{align*}
\frac{dq}{dp} &= \frac{1}{4}\left(-2 - 3\right) \quad \rightarrow \quad {\color{blue}\frac{dq}{dp}}\,&{\color{blue}= -\frac{5}{4}}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
To determine <math>q</math> when <math>p = 4</math> is simply a matter of substituting <math>p = 4</math> into the demand equation and solving for <math>q</math>.
:<math>
\begin{align}
q^{2} + p^{3/2} + 2p &= 20 \\
q^{2} + 8 + 8 &= 20 \\
q^{2} &= 4 \\
q &= \pm 2.
\end{align}
</math>
We ignore the negative solution since it is not possible to have negative demand. Therefore <math>{\color{blue}q = 2}.</math>

To determine <math>dq/dp</math>, we use implicit differentiation.
:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{d}{dp}\left(q^{2} + p^{3/2} + 2p\right) &= \frac{d}{dp}\left(20\right) \\
2q\frac{dq}{dp} + \frac{3}{2}p^{1/2} + 2 &= 0 \\
\frac{dq}{dp} &= \frac{1}{2q}\left(-2 - \frac{3}{2}p^{1/2} \right)
\end{align}
</math>
Substituting the values <math>p = 4,\,q = 2</math> into the expression gives the value of <math>dq/dp</math>:
:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{dq}{dp} &= \frac{1}{4}\left(-2 - 3\right) \quad \rightarrow \quad {\color{blue}\frac{dq}{dp}}\,&{\color{blue}= -\frac{5}{4}}
\end{align}
</math>
Instead of implicitly differentiating, we first solve the equation for ''q'' and then differentiate normally.  

:<math>\begin{align}
q^2+p^{3/2}+2p &=20 \\
q^2 &=20-p^{3/2}-2p \\
q &=\sqrt{20-p^{3/2}-2p}
\end{align}</math>

Then

:<math>\frac{dq}{dp} = \frac{-(3/2)p^{1/2}-2}{2\sqrt{20-p^{3/2}-2p}}</math>

Substituting in <math>p = 4</math> gives

:<math>\frac{dq}{dp} = \frac{-(3/2)(4)^{1/2}-2}{2\sqrt{20-(4)^{3/2}-2(4)}} = \frac{-(3/2)(2)-2}{2\sqrt{20-8-8}} = \frac{-5}{4} </math>
statement_html:
The demand equation for a certain product is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}q^2+p^{3/2}+2p=20\end{aligned}\]

where q is the number of units per hour the manufacturer can sell at a price of p dollars per unit.

Calculate q and \(\frac{\textrm{d}q}{\textrm{d}p}\) when the price is set at \$4.
statement_latex:
The demand equation for a certain product is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}q^2+p^{3/2}+2p=20
\end{align*}

where q is the number of units per hour the manufacturer can sell at a
price of p dollars per unit.

Calculate q and $\frac{\textrm{d}q}{\textrm{d}p}$ when the price is set
at \textbackslash{}\$4.
statement_raw:
The demand equation for a certain product is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}q^2+p^{3/2}+2p=20
</math>

where q is the number of units per hour the manufacturer can sell at a price of p dollars per unit.

Calculate q and <math>\frac{\textrm{d}q}{\textrm{d}p}</math> when the price is set at $4.
